author: mechtech
body:
Seems fairly uninformed. I can't read "And now, it’s just a matter of time before the performance of ARM-based chips continues its march upmarket into Intel’s last refuge: the server business" without immediately thinking that he has no idea of the very long and tumultuous history of big iron server ARM. Apple's lighting core is not going to be in the datacenter/server space. Ever. That's not how Apple works. They keep their vertically integrated tech as a competitive advantage and as a way to gate in innovation from other players that literally don't have the capability to copy it without playing "follow the leader", the cadence of which works to Apple's advantage.

If ARM stays independent then ARM is not breaking into servers any time soon. If NVIDIA gets ARM then it is highly likely that ARM will be in servers, but that's just the progression of the trend that's already happening with stream processing eating x86 market share. NVIDIA will not be slotting in ARM chips into chip sockets currently owned by Xeon and Threadripper, they have a very different vision for the datacenter and server space that involves deep vertical integration and dominant performance to justify it. Thus their purchase of Mellanox as a means to that end.

Intel is not screwed because of Apple (we've known about Apple ARM for many months now), it still comes down to AMD getting into the datacenter, server, and laptop space - areas where Intel has built it's behemoth size off of parts that they sell for thousands of dollars. Margins will be crushed, and Intel has insanely huge capex requirements due to running its own fabs. If Intel continues to have fab problems and has to execute an inevitably expensive transition to fabless while their margins are getting crushed, it's going to be another inflection point where investors are going to bail. That would probably be the buy-in time for a knife catcher, but I'd never buy it now. Their quarterly reports are so poor right now that every report has a serious risk of huge investment losses. Intel lied to investors for years about the severity of their fab problems, and Swan gets 0 leeway from investors. I remember how awful his first call was, how he was trying to blame China and how outright pissed the analysts were at his bullshit and how huge the resulting selloff was afterwards. It's really an important point that Intel has lost the trust of their investors, including institutions. These bad flow trends aren't going to reverse unless Intel perhaps kills it for a couple of quarters back to back, and that's not at all likely given the competitive landscape.

author: Objective_Stage
body:
Reading is dangerous so I mostly watched videos. Fastly solved a really hard problem (for some reason quickly deleting a specific tagged thing off a cache in under a few milliseconds is hard) and I'm not so sure the legacy cdns can do it without a massive redesign of their systems.

Fastly was built from the ground up to solve that problem, in particular. I think they're now getting more into doing actual compute at the edge. I don't know how much of a differentiator that is. I do know other CDNs have had like 9 years to catch up on instant cache deletes and haven't yet.

Then again I'm way too retarded to really understand it. I actually just like the name. Fastly. Just say it, it's like sex in ur mouth. FASTly.

author: Meymo
body:
If you’re a trader then it’s important to have an exit strategy. Paul was a trader who was trading soybean oil. He went all in and lost everything since he refused to exit a position that he was all in on. It the takeaway isn’t obvious, I’ll make it clear: Don’t go all in on anything. Ever. Sure, the upside can be great, but if the downside wipes you out then it’s not worth it.

As far as long-term investments are concerned, we have not seen a period where a well diversified portfolio goes to zero. The largest drawdown we’ve had was during the subprime crisis where if you were 100% invested in SPY, you’d end up with a 51% drawdown (later rebounded, but it was still a difficult time for many folks invested in the equities market). At the time, a bit of diversification with bonds would have gone a long way to prevent that 51% peak to trough drawdown (the 60/40 portfolio only had a 31% drawdown over that same period.)

If you’re in your positions for the long-term, you can take profits as you see fit. I sell into strength from time to time, especially if I have something that starts to grossly exceed my portfolio target allocation (eg if I have 5% in MSFT, and that position does ultra well and starts to take up 11% of my portfolio, I’ll take some chips off the table to get back to my target allocation). I also buy more on a regular cadence, so I’m constantly adding new money into the market.

Of course, if you just want to trade, then both timing of your positions and having a plan on your exits becomes very important. The simplest way to figure this out is to look at how much you’re willing to gain and lose, then set targets so that if they get hit you exit.

I’ve personally never found a consistent method of making money with trading, so I try to invest for the long term instead of worrying about day-to-day or even minute-to-minute scenarios. Different strokes for different folks though. Good luck!

author: FinndBors
body:
Okay, I watched the video and got dumber.

Seriously, there is no analysis on possible revenue at all. All he does is look at charts, say there are 3 events that might be worth 2 billion in market cap each coming up (2 billion per event is a number that is clearly out of his ass -- no consideration on whether these things are priced in) to justify a $50 dollar share price. A good chunk of the time talking about SPCE, he talks about the hype factor and how that could push the stock higher.

At the end of the day, how many people per year does SPCE need to fly up at 250k to break even? Can they get the customers and have the technical capability be able to fly at such a cadence?

I can do some basic back of the envelope math and it does not look like they can be anywhere near break even soon, unless you believe they can fly at least daily with maybe multiple spaceships. (really depends on actual margin -- which we don't have hard numbers on). I suggest you do the same. Unless they can raise more money by diluting shares in the next couple of years, they'll run out of money.

author: aske999
body:
Coming from the software side, they essentially are the highways of America. Think about how we transport goods in the context of roads. Usually there are the big highways that everyone shares and uses. However on the internet, nothing is stopping people from building their own roads except the cost, upkeep, and protection of the roads they built which can quickly spiral out of control.

Now imagine that there are companies that builds and privatizes their own roads. This is where CDNs like cloudflare come in. Want to get around a traffic jam? Some people will pay an arbitrary amount use your private road to bypass the jam and clouflare will serve them. They can also provide security and other amenities along their roads. The name of the game is scalability and presence here which takes a large amount of time to build up.

CDNs like cloudflare have good reputations and show little sign of stopping. You could look into Akamai to see a bigger player. Overall its an extremely safe stock considering the people behind it are really really good at their jobs.

author: snyder810
body:
I do think you’re right on how they’ll report, but the CDNs & fintech have been taking a beating. The upside seems to be a Visa reaction right now.

I cashed out both at 100% returns because I just didn’t see any more medium term upside given how fast they have grown when the market sentiment shifted. I think tech in general has entered a period where over the next few quarters the sentiment will be prove it to maintain, misstep at all and here’s your 20-30% fall. I hope I’m wrong, I like both companies, my strategy is just risk averse and willing sell when I feel uncomfortable with valuation. For the don’t time the market replies, that’s why the core of my own portfolio is buying the market with VOO & segment ETFs while augmenting with some select individuals. For any 0 div growth stocks I’m willing to cash out since they won’t compound at all should they stagnate or decline for an elongated period.

author: snyder810
body:
Been rough earnings for the CDNs, if NET doesn’t blow things away, or market sentiment hasn’t flipped, they look to have a chance to tumble back to mid-high 30s. Q4 is typically better for CDNs though, so could make for a buying opportunity if it happens. 

Personally if I was in a position where my cost position wasn’t established before the last jump up I probably wouldn’t hold through earnings, but I’ve been playing things pretty risk averse right now on stocks that won’t compound should we hit a period of decline/stagnation which I know isn’t everyone’s strategy.

author: ArtanisHero
body:
Two big things on your thesis:

1. A lot of the recent growth in the industry has been driven by rapid growth casual gaming (phones, tablets, etc.); I'm not saying more hardcore gaming on consoles and PC haven't grown, but just wanted to put this out there
2. The other big trend that isn't talked enough about it the movement towards game streaming - know there are latency issues today, etc. etc.; but your nuts if you don't think they're going to be able to overcome some of these technology hurdles in the future with advancements in internet speed, CDNs, edge computing, etc.  Think literally, Netflix for games - potential for no hardware and no physical software (or DLs) in the future - everything done steaming; this absolute kills GME's business model

author: Okmanl
body:
Most fund managers don’t beat the market. Because they’re not trying to. Many fund managers and professional investors also have regulations they have to follow. They can’t make concentrated investments. They have to show quarterly results and so forth. For example Cathy Wood said she would’ve put a lot more into Tesla but because of rules and regulations the max she can invest is ~10% per fund she manages. 


Individual investors can definitely beat the market by having a concentrated portfolio. Knowing the stock that they own intimately and not letting emotions get involved. 

There are quite a few people who have a concentrated portfolio on 3-4 companies like Square, peloton, Tesla, Amazon, Microsoft, AMD and so forth. And they have all outperformed the market over 5-10 years. 

If you have a high risk tolerance then buying single stocks can be worth it.

author: AngelaQQ
body:
Japan’s lost decades was a combination of fiscal mismanagement, overbearing debt load, and complete lack of technology growth, leading to stagnation.  

As a result, Japanese investors and savers pulled their money from the Nikkei and put it into US equities. Equities like Microsoft, Apple, Sun, Oracle saw a huge influx of Japanese capital as their markets stagnated.  

Even today, none of Japan’s top 20 companies by market cap are internet or software/tech companies. 

They’ve basically missed the boat on every single technological revolution of the past 30 years.

I’m not as worried about the US, because the US (and China) are the world leaders in technological innovation in almost all major sectors.

If there IS for some reason a lost decade in the US, China will benefit, as they are the only country that can compete technologically, and their debt position vis a vis the rest of world is favorable.

body: Nvidia is a safe investment in the long run (they might go down a bit this month though due to AMD, but overall Nvidia has went up consistently over the past 5 years and has shown no signs of deviating significantly from that), Microsoft is safe, Tesla is too scary for me personally. I don't buy ETFs or evaluate them, I evaluate individual stocks then choose whether or not I would like to purchase them. I play for large short term gains (large relative to my investment portfolio and short meaning a few months typically). I've made a 17.49% profit in the past 2 weeks (starting with 2k) due to making "all in" bets on Corsair (to be clear to do this I was incredibly confident it was going to go up, but I definitely wouldn't advise it if you do not need the money, I have a stupidly low retirement target). Corsair was likely my most risky investment that's why I left quickly. AMD and TSMC are great investments for a couple of years, probably 3 years or more (TSMC almost definitely 3 years or more since they make the most powerful CPUs that go in the new Xbox, PS5, AMD CPUs, Apple CPUs, and they even have Intel waiting in line since their factories are all in use). You'll almost definitely hate my diversity, but I'm likely going to buy all AMD and TSMC (In my opinion diversity is for people who don't know much about the market they are invested in or don't feel like keeping up with the news). If I were to make a more long-term safer account I'd buy NVidia, Apple, AMD, and TSMC (Diversification in different sectors doesn't help if the entire market goes down, and I don't believe these specific tech stocks have exited a year down for the past decade (I know at least for the past 5 years they haven't), except for AMD which completely changed as a company). I'm putting all of my money on AMD and TSMC once the market opens tomorrow (I'd recommend stocking up ASAP on those stocks since they had a bad day on Friday). Apple will likely not see that much growth if any this quarter, but they'll be great for the long term. If you don't have the stomach or patience for seeing temporary losses then I would not recommend tech (Microsoft isn't too bad actually). I've sat on 200 USD losses (which is 10% of my portfolio) and went positive 145 USD the next day (that was my worst timed trade with Corsair). It's easy to see that Zoom is (was?) undervalued. People are having more meetings online because of covid-19, and a lot of them are using Zoom. It seems everywhere you look someone has an online meeting on Zoom. Schools that are closed have classes on Zoom.   
Zoom seems to be like the Microsoft of online meetings these days, it's the de-facto industry standard for online meetings. So on that basis alone, Zoom seems undervalued (at this point in time.) 

They're more popular now than they ever were, and that potentially means more money, and that in turn means the price might go up.   


The thing about active trading is, well, that it's active. The fund managers try to figure out what will go up and buy it, and sell it before it drops. They're more momentum players than long-term holders, so I guess based on that alone they might buy Zoom (because everyone seems to be using it these days, and that can't be a bad thing as far as the price is concerned (for now anyway.)  


There was a lot of hype around Zoom, and when it appeared on a lot of people's radars it was a lot cheaper than it is now.  They would have likely bought in when they first started seeing all those ads for seminars on Zoom, and notices of schools being closed and having classes on Zoom.

author: StarWolf478
body:
The big two for me are:

Netflix - The Q2 lockdown was the absolute most perfect condition imaginable for Netflix's business and anybody that had any interest in Netflix should have already subscribed by that point in time. I think that there now has to be some significant growth slowdown after such perfect business conditions start to come to an end. Plus, more and more competitors are entering the market to compete for Netflix's subscribers while also pulling their content from Netflix which forces Netflix to spend more money to develop their own content. All of that makes me think that Netflix cannot maintain the high growth that they have had thus far and if they can't maintain that growth then investors will eventually start to abandon them. I'm still bullish on streaming though, so I've invested in Roku instead as my streaming stock since they are the "picks and shovels seller" for the "streaming gold rush" and unlike Netflix, they benefit from the increased competition entering the streaming market.

Google - They have started to remind me of Microsoft during the Steve Ballmer era. When was the last time that Google successfully executed upon a great new product and didn't ultimately send it to ever growing [Google Graveyard](https://killedbygoogle.com/)? I think that it has been about a decade and they have just been living off of their successes from over a decade ago since then. Maybe Google will eventually get new management that revitalizes the company like Microsoft eventually got after Nadella became CEO, but for the foreseeable future, I've lost confidence in them, so I'm out. I've replaced them with Pinterest in my portfolio as my new search/advertising stock. Social search is the future and I now see the genius advertising potential of the Pinterest platform; I see them stealing advertising dollars away from Google and growing much better than Google over the next 5 years.

author: thewimsey
body:
MSFT wasn't  a computer company. It was a software company. IBM was a computer company.

The brilliance of MSFT was in - and this seems weird today - realizing that a company could make money just selling software. A ton of money. More money than computer makers could make by themselves. This was a kind of radical idea at the time.

Jobs was very successful at the computer business; the Apple was the bestselling PC from 1977-1982.

Apple wasn't killed by MSFT, it was killed by IBM, which built a PC from more or less off the shelf parts allowing *anyone* to build a clone. (Which, incidentally, would run windows). 

Apple's computers couldn't compete with PCs built with off the shelf parts. It's not about Jobs being bad; it's about other people being better.

IBM's approach almost immediately priced *them* out of the PC market, leaving the profits to MSFT and intel (and a tiny bit for clone makers, who mostly ended up in a low margin commodity business).

author: ZarrCon
body:
One way I like to visualize dividend growth investing is by using Visa as an example. A lot of people might look at its current yield of 0.70% and think it would be a terrible dividend stock to own because they yield is so low. But when you look at the actual dividend amounts things start to become a lot more clear.

In 2009, Visa paid a dividend of $0.10 a share. In 2019 they paid a dividend of $1.00 a share. Visa's stock price was around $20 in 2009, so if we use that as our cost basis, the current dividend yield we'd be receiving from shares purchased in 2009 would be 5% (known as yield on cost). So basically even though Visa currently yields 0.70% to anyone buying today, that doesn't mean everyone holding shares is making 0.70% on their investment. 

This is one of the reasons Warren Buffet has been so successful over the years. For example, his cost basis on Coca Cola is $3.25 per share, and the stock currently pays a dividend of $1.64 per share. This means Buffet's yield on cost is over 50%. He invested $1.3B in KO back in the late 80s and early 90s, and will now collect $654 million in income from the stock this year alone.

author: cbus20122
body:
>that if we’re faced with low growth and inflation expectations then this is where assets should be priced.

Based on what model? Low growth + inflation implies higher real rates, which imply strong tightening of financial conditions. You think in that scenario stocks are priced rationally?

The whole narrative that stocks are expensive because yields are low should work both ways. If yields rise (due to inflation) stocks should then see a lot of selling, especially in longer duration exposures.

Low growth + inflation expectations, if that were to actually occur, implies heavy P/E contraction in the coming years. That's assuming those expectations are actually discounting the correct things which they very well may not be.

That either gives you a 1970's type scenario, in which bonds get wrecked and stocks tread water relative to inflation, or more of a depression type deflationary scenario, in which case stocks **surely** are not priced properly.

The issue with any inflationary scenario is that if it truly gets going in any form (scenario 1 here where we see something similar to the 70's), we're in for a lot more trouble than we can handle. There is far too much debt for the economy to handle inflation pressures, and any increase in bond yields will result in massive tightening of financial conditions. That scenario likely ends up leading into a deflationary spiral in the end. There is a reason we saw a 20% drawdown in 2018. The global economy simply can't handle rate increases which inflation would cause.

As for any comparison to the the 1970's, the macro environment then was far different than now - they had very strong demographics, very low non-public debt, and the inflation was largely based on **demand** along with a few supply shocks\*\*.\*\* Globally, we couldn't be more opposite of that right now.

Overall, the only particularly great argument for valuations right now is that there simply are no other great alternatives, and there has been no need to de-leverage due to the ability to lower rates and keep yields at or below zero globally. This, and the fact that unlike 08', governments are doing their best to not allow defaults of major companies, which has kept the market at least relatively orderly and prevented forced de-leveraging.

In my personal opinion, the trigger for any real longer-term recession or depression of any sort will come from inflation rising past an ever-falling threshold of growth. The "level" of financial tightening represented by yields has been falling for 40 years.

* In 08', they over-tightened to the point where 5% caused the debt overburden to blow things up.
* In 2018, 2.5% was getting far too tight, mandating emergency rate cuts going into 2019.

Now? Debt burdens have expanded drastically post-covid, and banks are not lending very much at all. This causes a drawdown in supply, which increases overall inflation on a longer-term basis. So you get a scenario where the economy likely couldn't handle bond rates much past 1% (and that's being incredibly generous), yet the conditions for future inflation **relative to real growth** are growing.

I certainly don't think the financial system is going to blow up tomorrow by any means, but we are getting close to the boundaries of the financial system to keep operating in the same way it has over the last 40 years, and any significant change, which becomes more likely the closer we get to those boundaries implies strong turbulence in the next 3-5 years.

author: rymor
body:
The way I see it, the only real risk is opportunity cost, but there are several aspects to that. 

If you have money in PIC, and the market crashes, the common shares might drop by only 5% to $9.50 while the market drops 30%. That’s good news, but what do you do now? 

If you think the market is set for a quick recovery, you probably pull the SPAC money out and put it into AAPL or AMZN, hoping for a 35% bounce. 

So, in that case, you would have been better off in cash when the market was shaky. The SPAC (eg PIC) will recover, to at least $10 and probably more. But it won’t give you a 35% recovery. So you’ve essentially given up 5% for your capital for no reason. 

 Now, if you think the market will be consistently bad, you might stick it out and try to play the quasi arbitrage game. The SPACs you purchase below their trust value might earn you 2-5% if a) the share price recovers, or b) you redeem your shares at the merger vote. 

If the latter, that could be a long wait. If the former, the overall market is likely to recover more quickly than PIC. PIC will bounce back to $10 right away, but AAPL is likely to hit $120 before PIC hits $11. 

So, that’s sort of the paradox of SPACs as I see it. I’m currently parked in QELL, DGNR, IPOF, CCIV, RBAC, RTP, and SOAC. 

If the market stays choppy for a few for months, which is likely (I don’t think we get any stimulus until Feb or so after a long drawn-out battle)... then SPACs might be a decent play... CCIV, SOAC, etc could announce a target and the price could jump 20% or more while the overall market is ranging. That’s a win. 

But if the market is really bad, they’ll probably wait to announce an agreement, so you don’t gain much there. And if the market does bounce back (eg sooner than expected stimulus), you’re probably better off in AMZN.

The best SPAC play IMO is to be in cash in choppy market, and if/when the market plummets, scoop up warrants and units of the better SPACs at discounted prices (eg $9.50 for tier one units; sub $1 warrants for the best management team SPACs). 

But then again, if you’re able to time the market that well, you could buy SHOP or LULU at deep discounts and do just as well.

author: mrh0057
body:
The stock market is way overvalued and you need to understand more of why.  You can look at things like P/E ratios and that but there is another elephant in the room right now people are ignoring.  Most of the world's population is getting older and there will be a significantly smaller number of people working per retiree and wages have been flat or going down.  Then you have increased expenses for housing and healthcare (US only).  There already is negative outflows for years and no one is talking about what happens as it accelerates as boomers retire.  The stock market started to go up significantly when the US switched from pension funds to 401k.  Granted there are other factors driving the economy but you now have a significant flow of new money into the market. 

BTW, bonds are sold in markets and auctions so if the rate is low that means a significant portion of the investment world thinks the economy isn't in great shape.  Have to ask yourself why are willing to lend money so cheaply.  The bond market is something like 3x bigger than the stock market.  So the bonds are saying we don't believe the current rally and why would they when corporate profits have been nearly flat since 2012 before COVID and now have decreased significantly.

As long as LYV can make it out alive until restrictions are lifted... the only competitor in there way will be pretty much AEG and they can continue its pre-COVID momentum. Warning... the stock hasn't dropped a lot for a company that is in a cash crunch and has +95% revenue decrease, which surprises me. E
What won't surprise me if the stock drops to $20 - $45 and I'll be a buyer.

V and MA: Should also accelerate growth once a vaccine is available and transactions are lifted. They should recover a big chunk of their spending volume and cross-border fees, but I think business travel is permanently impaired. Right now I'm a V holder, but I like PYPL a bit more as my favorite fintech.
